facts.text: 32 petitions under Article 32 of the Constitution challenging the constitutional validity of the Himachal Pradesh Abolition of Big Landed Estates and Land Reforms Act, 1953 (Himachal 15 of 1954).

anchor.surface_text: the respective petitioners challenge the constitutional validity of the Himachal Pradesh Abolition of Big Landed Estates and Land Reforms Act, 1953.  Himachal 15 of 1954  which is said, to have been passed by the,.Legislative Assembly of the State of Himachal Pradesh created by the Himachal Pradesh and Bilaspur  New State  Act  32 of 1954 .

facts.text: Himachal Pradesh Abolition of Big Landed Estates and Land Reforms Act, 1953 (Himachal 15 of 1954) passed by the Legislative Assembly of the State of Himachal Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: Himachal Pradesh Abolition of Big Landed Estates and Land Reforms Act, 1953.  Himachal 15 of 1954  which is said, to have been passed by the,.Legislative Assembly of the State of Himachal Pradesh created by the Himachal Pradesh and Bilaspur  New State  Act  32 of 1954 . On November 23, 1954, the President of India gave his assent

facts.text: President of India gave assent to the Bill on November 23, 1954, making it the Himachal Pradesh Abolition of Big Landed Estates and Land Reforms Act, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: On November 23, 1954, the President of India gave his assent to the Bill which on being so assented to became the Himachal Pradesh Abolition of Big Landed Estates and Land Reforms Act, 1953,  Himachal 15 of 1954   hereinafter called the Abolition Act .

facts.text: Abolition Act brought into force on January 26, 1955 by notification under section 1(3).

anchor.surface_text: On January 26, 1955, this Abolition Act was brought into force by a notification issued under s. 1 3  thereof.

facts.text: Petitioners are all landowners who moved court under Art. 32 for enforcement of fundamental rights to property.

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, not surprising that the petitioners in all these petitions, all of whom are landowners, have moved this Court by separate petitions under Art. 32 for the enforcement of their fundamental rights to their respective properties.

facts.text: Petitioners challenge that the Abolition Act is void for not having been passed by a duly constituted legislature.

anchor.surface_text: In each of the several petitions which have been heard together two broad points have been taken, namely- That the Abolition Act is entirely void by reason of its not having been passed by a duly constituted legislature

facts.text: Bilaspur and Himachal Pradesh were separate Part C States in First Schedule to Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: In the First Schedule to the Constitution, as it was originally passed, were set out under the heading Part C States the names of 10 States. In that list of Part C States Bilaspur was shown as item 3 and Himachal Pradesh as item 7.

facts.text: Government of Part C States Act, 1951 (49 of 1951) provided for Legislative Assemblies for Part C States except Bilaspur.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of Part C States Act  49 of 1951 , hereinafter referred to as the Part C States Act , provides for Legislative Assemblies, Councils of Ministers and Councils of Advisers for Part C States.

facts.text: Old Himachal Pradesh had 36 seats in Legislative Assembly per Third Schedule of Part C States Act.

anchor.surface_text: According to the Third Schedule, as it stood originally, the total number of seats allocated to the old Himachal Pradesh was 36 including 8 seats reserved for scheduled castes.

facts.text: Elections held in 1952 for old Himachal Pradesh, 36 members elected.

anchor.surface_text: In exercise of the powers conferred on him by s. 4 of the Part C States Act, the President duly made an order, determining the constituencies into which the old Himachal Pradesh would be divided and thereafter in 1952 elections were duly held and 36 members were elected

facts.text: Bill (Himachal 15 of 1953) introduced in first session of old Himachal Pradesh Legislative Assembly in 1953.

anchor.surface_text: It was in this first session of this Legislative Assembly of the old Himachal Pradesh that in 1953 a Bill  Himachal 15 of 1953  which became the Abolition Act was introduced.

facts.text: Himachal Pradesh and Bilaspur New State Act, 1954 (32 of 1954) enacted on May 8, 1954, assented May 28, 1954, into force July 1, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Pending the passage of that bill into an Act Parliament, on May 8, 1954, enacted an Act called the Himachal Pradesh and Bilaspur  New State  Act  32 of 1954 , hereinafter I referred to as the New State Act . This Act received the assent of the President on May 28, 1954, and was brought into force

facts.text: New State Act created new Part C State of Himachal Pradesh by uniting old Himachal Pradesh and Bilaspur.

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 of the New State Act says As from the commencement of this Act there shall be formed by uniting the existing States a new Part C State to be known as the State of Himachal Pradesh  hereafter in this Act referred to as the new State  .

facts.text: New State Act provides for Legislative Assembly of 41 seats.

anchor.surface_text: Section 12 provides as follows 12.  1  There shall be a Legislative Assembly for the new State. The total number of seats in that Legislative Assembly which shall be filled by direct election shall be 41.

facts.text: Notification dated July 7, 1954 summoning second session of Himachal Pradesh Legislative Assembly on August 16, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime, on July 7, 1954, to be precise, the following notification was issued in the official Gazette- Legislative Assembly NOTIFICATION Simla-4, the 7th July, 1954. No. L.A.-109-28/54-The Lieutenant Governor, in exercise of the powers conferred by. section 9 of the Government of Part C States Act, 1951  XLIX of 1951 , has been pleased to direct that the Second Session, 1954, of the Himachal Pradesh Legislative Assembly will commence from Monday, the 16th August, 1954,

facts.text: No notification declaring 36 members of old assembly as members of new assembly before summoning notification.

anchor.surface_text: It is not in dispute that, prior to the date of the aforesaid notification summoning the Legislative Assembly, no notification was issued by the appropriate authority declaring the 36 persons who had been the members of the old Legislative Assembly of the old Himachal Pradesh as members of the new Legislative Assembly

facts.text: 36 members of old assembly did not make fresh oath or affirmation as members of new assembly.

anchor.surface_text: Nor is it in dispute that the 36 members of the old Legislative Assembly of the old Himachal Pradesh did not, in point of fact, make or subscribe any fresh oath or affirmation as members of the new Legislative Assembly of the new Himachal Pradesh

facts.text: No election of Speaker for the new Legislative Assembly.

anchor.surface_text: as required by s. 14 of the Part C States Act, which is on the same lines as Arts. 99 and 108 of the Constitution or that they elected a Speaker under s. 10 of that Act.

facts.text: Five members elected on May 13, 1955 from Bilaspur area constituencies to bring total to 41.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, on May 13, 1955, five members were elected by the voters of the constituencies of that area so delimited so as to bring up the total number of members of the new Legislative Assembly of the new Himachal Pradesh to 41 as prescribed by s. 12 of the New State Act.

facts.text: Court holds that the Legislative Assembly that passed the Abolition Act was not the properly constituted Legislative Assembly of the new Himachal Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the so called Legislative Assembly which was convened and which purported to pass the Abolition Act was not the Legislative Assembly of the new Himachal Pradesh created by the New State Act, therefore, the impugned Act cannot be regarded as a piece of validity enacted legislation.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on October 10, 1958 by DAS, C.J.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. October 10. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS, C. J.-By each of these 32 petitions under Art. 32 of our Constitution, which have been heard together, the respective petitioners challenge

facts.text: Old Himachal Pradesh and Bilaspur ceased to exist after New State Act; new Himachal Pradesh created.

anchor.surface_text: The true legal position admittedly is that as a result of the New State Act the old Himachal Pradesh as well as the old State of Bilaspur both ceased to exist and there sprang to life a new Himachal Pradesh having for its territory the aggregate of the separate territories of the two defunct States

facts.text: Notification summoned 'second session' of 1954, despite no prior session of new assembly.

anchor.surface_text: The fact that the Lieutenant Governor did not intend to summon a meeting of the new Legislative Assembly of the new Himachal Pradesh is made clear by the fact that by the notification in question he convened what he described as the second ,session of the Legislative Assembly.

facts.text: No oath administered to 36 members at the summoned session.

anchor.surface_text: This conclusion is further reinforced by the fact that no oath or affirmation was administered to the 36 persons when they assembled in pursuance of the summons as required by s. 14 of the Part C States Act

facts.text: No election of Speaker at the summoned session; old Speaker granted leave.

anchor.surface_text: as well as by the further fact that the Legislative Assembly which was summoned by the Lieutenant Governor under s. 9 of the Part C States Act did not choose any of the members to be the Speaker of that Legislative Assembly.

issues.text: Whether the Abolition Act is entirely void by reason of its not having been passed by a duly constituted legislature?

anchor.surface_text: That the Abolition Act is entirely void by reason of its number having been passed by a duly companystituted legislature and That, in any event, the provisions of Ch. III and of Ch. VIII are repugnant to the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether the provisions of Ch. III and of Ch. VIII of the Abolition Act are repugnant to the Constitution?

anchor.surface_text: and That, in any event, the provisions of Ch. III and of Ch. VIII are repugnant to the Constitution. Re i In the First Schedule to the Constitution, as it was originally passed, were set out under the heading Part C States the names of 10 States.

issues.text: Whether the so-called Legislative Assembly convened by the Lieutenant Governor was the Legislative Assembly of the new Himachal Pradesh?

anchor.surface_text: The problem before us is to determine which Assembly the Lieutenant Governor had convened. In our opinion the so called Legislative Assembly which was convened and which purported to pass the Abolition Act was number the Legislative Assembly of the new Himachal Pradesh created by the New State Act,

arguments.claim: Section 15(1) of New State Act deems 36 sitting members elected to new Legislative Assembly, constituting it immediately with 36 members

anchor.surface_text: The learned Additional Solicitor General takes his stand on s. 15 of the New State Act which has already been quoted in full. According to sub-s. (1) of that section every sitting member of the Legislative Assembly of the existing State of Himachal Pradesh representing a constituency of the said State shall, on and from the commencement of this Act, represent the constituency of the same name in the new State and shall be deemed to have been elected to the Legislative Assembly of the new State by that constituency.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ation of the deeming provision embodied in s. 15 1  the 36 members have been placed in the same position as they would have been placed in had they go

arguments.court_reasoning: s.15(1) only deems elected, obviates fresh election; does not constitute assembly - still needs s.74 ROP notification, oath s.14, speaker s.10

arguments.claim: Absence of 5 members from Bilaspur does not vitiate proceedings due to power to act notwithstanding vacancies under s.35 Part C States Act

anchor.surface_text: The learned Additional Solicitor General maintains that the fact that five members had not been elected from- the constituencies of the area which was formerly comprised in the territories of the State of Bilaspur did not vitiate the proceedings, for the Legislative Assembly had, under s. 15 3 of the Part C States Act, power to act notwithstanding any vacancy in the membership thereof.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ompanystituted and brought into being until five members from the Bilaspur area had been elected so as to bring the total number of members to 41 as p

arguments.court_reasoning: s.35 applies to irregularities in existing assembly, not to case where no assembly constituted at all

arguments.claim: Failure of 36 members to take fresh oath is mere irregularity cured by s.35 Part C States Act (corresponding to Arts.100(2),189(2))

anchor.surface_text: The learned Additional Solicitor General concedes that strictly speaking the 36 members of the old Legislative Assembly of the old Himachal Pradesh who, by the fiction created by s. 15 1 of the New State Act had become members of the new Legislative Assembly of the new Himachal Pradesh, should have made and subscribed a fresh oath or affirmation but that the absence of that formality is a mere irregularity which, by virtue of s. 15 3 of the Part C States Act corresponding to Arts. 100 2 and 189 2 of the Constitution, did not vitiate the proceedings

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ompanystituted and brought into being until five members from the Bilaspur area had been elected so as to bring the total number of members to 41 as p

arguments.court_reasoning: s.35 postulates existing duly constituted assembly; no assembly brought into being; also evidence of no intent to constitute new assembly

arguments.claim: New State Act created new Part C State of Himachal Pradesh; old Himachal Pradesh and Bilaspur ceased to exist

anchor.surface_text: The true legal position admittedly is that as a result of the New State Act the old Himachal Pradesh as well as the old State of Bilaspur both ceased to exist and there sprang to life a new Himachal Pradesh having for its territory the aggregate of the separate territories of the two defunct States

arguments.claim: No fresh oath or affirmation by 36 members as required by s.14 Part C States Act
